newsitem.title: USA: Bell Atlantic backs 1997 EPS estimates.
newsitem.headline: Bell Atlantic backs 1997 EPS estimates.

text.p: U.S. telephone company Bell Atlantic Corp said Monday it was comfortable with Wall Street earnings estimates of $4.90 per share to $5.00 for the year.

Bell, which completed its merger with NYNEX Corp on August 14, said in a statement that it had also set a target range of 10 percent to 12 percent for long-term annual growth of its earnings per share.

"We're confident that the power of our merger will allow us to sustain that kind of performance over the next few years, even while the communications industry goes through a period of dramatic transition," it said.
The consensus among analysts surveyed by First Call was for Bell Atlantic to show a profit of $4.94 per share this year and $5.41 for the next 12 months.
Bell also said it filed pro forma earnings for the past three and a half years with the Securities and Exchange Commission, after completing the $25.6 billion merger.

It said adjusted earnings for the second quarter of 1997 were $1.25 per share, 12.6 percent higher than the same period a year ago. Adjusted earnings per share for the first six months of 1997 were $2.46, an increase of 12.8 percent from the previous year, it said.

Bell Atlantic said pro forma adjusted earnings per share, which exclude the effects of special items disclosed previously by the separate companies, grew 10 percent in 1996 to $4.49 from $4.08 the previous year.
For 1995, pro forma adjusted earnings per share grew 10.3 percent from $3.70 in 1994, it said.
The telecommunications company has 40 million telephone access lines and 5.5 million wireless customers.
